mods:mods.mods:abstract: Since the last letter sent to John Jay by Mr. Bayard about November 1, Washington has received letters dated 13 September and 2 October from Jay. Concerning the opinions of Mr. M-'s communication to the National Convention of France, Washington will only observe that the neutrality of the United States "does not appear to have been well digested," and that Mr. M-, anticipating criticism of his conduct, now says that the navy, officers and privateers of France who came to our ports had been placed under such neutral restrictions as "represented this country (and not without effect) as unfriendly to the French revolution. ``This Mr. M- found necessary to counteract...by strong assurances of the good disposition we bore to the Nation." Washington agrees with Jay that Mr. M-"stepped over the line," although "bringing matters to a happy and speedy result" is something "ardently wished for by the friends and peace and good order in this country." The Secretary of state has been unable to find out from Bache, in whose gazette the information first appeared, where he got the report that the United States may be chosen as mediator between France and England. The British escheats on Virginia land do not rest on the grounds given to Jay. Washington will have the Secretary of State send Jay a copy of the principles involved.
mods:mods.mods:note: The entire content of the original has been digitized.
mods:mods.mods:accessCondition: For rights relating to this resource, visit http://www.columbia.edu/cu/lweb/digital/jay/copyright.html
